Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can illustrate a material before it is either heated or cooled, showing its original state.
The student can depict what happens to a material after it is heated (e.g., ice turning to water, egg solidifying).
The student can draw whether the change in the material is reversible, showing a reversible change such as water turning back to ice, or an irreversible change like a cooked egg staying solid.
The student can illustrate a material after cooling to show how it may revert back to its original state, if possible (e.g., water freezing back to ice).
The student can use drawings to show a change that cannot be reversed by cooling or heating (e.g., a cooked egg cannot become raw again).
The student can represent an observable pattern caused by heating or cooling (e.g., the predictable pattern of ice melting and refreezing).
